column4: that dist-upgrade interested me too, is there anything bad about it? will it completely upgrade my system or some things will be left?
it will completely upgrade everything
just if new default packages are added to dapper you'll need to pull them in using apt-get or synaptic
so all the packages, desktop environment, kernel, everything will be replaced just as I installed them?
i.e. there is a new network monitor program...and unless you do a fresh installations or install it manually later...it will be left off
to your question:  yes
and then I'll have dapper and no more breezy so I continue using dappers repositories, right?
yup
the beauty of a debian-based system is that you can never have to reinstall
yeh I have noticed that package system works flawlesly
just change sources.list to point to dapper and apt-get dist-upgrade and viola
I was using suse but it is no near to ubuntu or debian
it's the best package management system out there....portage is the only package manager that comes close
yeah you can get into a RPM nightmare
but portage is about sources, while debs are still binarys which makes it even simpler...
not can get... been there, done that :P it's terrible... rpms suck...
and that yast, like it never heard of word dependency...
yeah rpms do you suck...yeah portage is sources but when i used gentoo i never had dependency problems i just got tired of compiling everything
I thought going for gentoo too, but then I though of compiling everything, and I sit back and went for ubuntu
yeah ubuntu is nice because if you want to tinker you still can
but gentoo there are just no packages and it can be a friggin' hassle to wait 24 hours to use oo.org2
anyway, ubuntu works just great for me... although suse is a bit simpler to use because of so many gui tools, there is nothing in suse that makes it better than ubuntu
yeah
I have been compiling from sources some programs on suse and on ubuntu... on ubuntu they work flawleslly while on suse for each one of them I spent whole afternoon
